paper_abstract: Let alpha(1),...,alpha(k) satisfy Sigma(i) alpha(i) = 1 and suppose a k-uniform hypergraph on n vertices satisfies the following property; in any partition of its vertices into k sets A(1),...,A(k) of sizes alpha(1)n,...,alpha(k)n, the number of edges intersecting A(1),...,A(k) is (asymptotically) the number one would expect to find in a random k-uniform hypergraph. Can we then infer that H is quasi-random? We show that the answer is negative if and only if alpha(1) = ... = alpha(k) = 1/k. This resolves an open problem raised in 1991 by Chung and Graham [J AMS 4 (1991), 151-196]. While hypergraphs satisfying the property corresponding to alpha(1) = ... = alpha(k) = 1/k are not necessarily quasi-random, we manage to find a characterization of the hypergraphs satisfying this property. Somewhat surprisingly, it turns out that (essentially) there is a unique non quasi-random hypergraph satisfying this property. The proofs combine probabilistic and algebraic arguments with results from the theory of association schemes. (C) 2011 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Random Struct. Alg., 40, 105-131, 2012
paper_title: The quasi-randomness of hypergraph cut properties
